title: 6 Compelling Benefits of Meditation, According to Science
author: Jane Claire Hervey Updated Jun
description: Meditation benefits include everything from relaxation to improving your brain function, and more. Here's why you should give it a try.
cleaned_text: 6 Compelling Benefits of Meditation, According to Science Don't dismiss this practice until you consider these medical reasons for giving [meditation](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/change-in-you-15-minutes-meditation/) a chance What are the benefits of meditation? Have you answered the call to [meditate](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/meditation-mistakes-secretly-stress-you-out/) yet? Proponents of the practice point out its bevy of perks, including [lowering blood pressure](https://www.thehealthy.com/high-blood-pressure/avoid-high-blood-pressure/), boosting mood, and decreasing pain. "What meditation is doing is allowing yourself space and time to tune into your parasympathetic nervous system, which tones down or switches off the sympathetic "fight or flight" system, which is so commonly in overdrive within each of us on a daily basis," says Lana Butner, a naturopathic doctor and licensed acupuncturist with Tru Whole Care in New York City. To start, she recommends committing to three minutes each in the morning and evening to meditate. Use an [app](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/meditation-apps/) like Calm, Headspace, Insight Timer, or INSCAPE, suggests Butler. (Check out these [free meditation](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/free-meditation/) resources too.) Meditation might be a more powerful painkiller than morphine Meditation may be able to help decrease your perception of pain, says Butler, prompting a "mind over matter" response to what's irking you. In a 2016 study published in The Journal of Neuroscience, a specific technique called [mindfulness meditation](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26985045/) (nonjudgmental awareness to events) helped significantly [reduce pain](https://www.thehealthy.com/pain/natural-pain-relief/) intensity and "unpleasantness" when participants were administered a painful heat stimuli and given an IV of either an opioid drug or placebo saline. (Learn when the [best time to meditate](https://www.thehealthy.com/mental-health/best-time-to-meditate/) is in order to reap the most benefits.) An "om" a day could keep your blood pressure at bay If you have [high blood pressure](https://www.thehealthy.com/heart-disease/foods-that-help-lower-high-blood-pressure/), following a low-sodium diet and taking medication as prescribed is critical. Add "meditate" to your treatment plan, too. Research in the Journal of Human Hypertension in 2019 found that patients with high blood pressure who took part in an 8-week [mindfulness](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30425326/) training program were able to lower both their levels of systolic and diastolic blood pressure levels. If you want to try adding meditation to your routine for this potential benefit, follow these [meditation tips](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/meditation-tips/) to sneak it into your everyday life. It might make you smarter Stay sharp for life: A 2018 study in Scientific Reports found that just 40 minutes of meditation (specifically "mindful breath awareness meditation") helped improve [cognitive performance](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-32046-5) by improving attention networks in the brain. These benefits may keep your brain young, too, possibly because meditation [reduces stress](https://www.thehealthy.com/mental-health/stress/ways-reduce-stress/). "It seems that individuals with chronically elevated stress are more likely to develop mild cognitive impairment as they age, which could greatly impact quality of life," says Kalea Wattles, ND, a functional medicine physician with Vida Integrated Health in Bellvue, WA. "Studies are showing changes to the actual structure of the brain induced by [meditation](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29466242/), as well as enhanced brain function associated with stress reduction," she adds. (Find out [how long you should meditate](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/how-long-should-you-meditate/) in order to get the benefits.) Meditating could decrease risk of depression A meditative practice can give you a [mood lift](https://www.thehealthy.com/mental-health/happiness/easy-ways-to-boost-your-mood/). "Meditation, particularly mindfulness-based practices, can be helpful for [anxiety and depression](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24395196/)," says Wattles. "In fact, the practice has been shown to be comparable to pharmaceutical antidepressants in the treatment of mild depression in the primary care setting," she says. (Learn more about practicing [meditation for depression](https://www.thehealthy.com/mental-health/depression/meditation-for-depression/) treatment.) You'll actually relax Mindfulness meditation can help quiet emotional turbulence and [anxiety](https://www.thehealthy.com/mental-health/anxiety/how-to-deal-with-anxiety/), says Marianela Medrano, PhD, owner at Palabra Counseling & Training Center in Stamford, CT. "When you're breathing, more oxygen goes to the brain, and when your brain is well-fed with oxygen you think better. They report the ability of being more in control of themselves," she explains. Get started with these [meditation quotes](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/meditation-quotes/) to keep you grounded. Meditation makes you happy The feel-good vibes last long after the session itself. "In the long-term, meditation could actually shift brain activity towards happiness and contentment. There is evidence that experienced meditators have less activation in brain regions associated with mind wandering," says Wattles. As a result, they're more able to stay in the moment, something that improves life satisfaction. Remember, meditation is a learned practice. If you're struggling to clear your mind in the beginning, have a laugh at these [meditation memes](https://www.thehealthy.com/alternative-medicine/meditation-meme/).
